justification: “In contrast, a price task can determine the present or certain value of a delayed or risky outcome through a single trial… making them more easily fit by statistical models” – indicating the pricing task is used to measure subjective value/preference.

“Choice tasks tend to either present a fixed set of choices… or present two options and titrate… until a static indifference point is found” – describing the use of choice tasks to elicit subjective value.

“Increasing payoffs x are related to their subjective utility u(x) by a power-law utility function… Typical values of α < 1 yield a concave function representing diminishing marginal utility” – α is the quantitative measure of payoff utility.
“Delayed outcomes tend to decrease in value … by a hyperbolic function… Higher values of k indicate a higher rate of delay discounting” – k serves as the metric for the construct.

“The subjective weight of an outcome w(p) is related… by an inverse s-shaped probability weighting function… Values of b less than 1 result in low probabilities being subjectively more likely…” – b quantifies the probability-weighting construct.
“Unlike typical accounts of loss aversion where the subjective value of a loss… is multiplied by the coefficient λ as a free parameter” – λ is identified as the standard measure of loss aversion.
